Replies.Reply: Would you like to see...
Excuse me?
Are you sure?
People make mistakes in times of grief.
Oh shit!
I'm sorry, man. I got a little nervous. This almost never happens.
I think I know where he is.
Don't worry. I'll get him, man.
So is this your father?
Just trying to be professional. What up, Michelle?
Brian... who is that?
Who is this man I'm looking at?
Are you asking me if I'm sure I know what my father looks like?
Man, look at the damn body!
Come on, Brian. You know what my father looks like. He used to take you to little league.
It's happened before?! You mean this is a normal thing?... This isn't Burger King. You can't just mess up my order.
You think?
I better .,see my dad in this coffin in an hour, or you're going to take his place.
You do that.
My people, my people, my people...
They brought the wrong body. Can you believe that?
They think so. They're getting him now.
You were right. Please don't rub it in, not today. I've got so much to worry about.
Dad insisted on having the funeral here, Mom's crying all the time, Ryan didn't help with anything, not like he ever does! Plus my eulogy sucks. I can't wait until this day is over.
If it is, at least Dad's too dead to hear it.
It doesn't matter what I write. All anybody's going to be thinking is "why isn't Ryan doing the eulogy? Even I'm going to be thinking it.
Soon. It's not ready to be read yet.
I said I'd take care of it and I'll take care of it.
Hey, hey, hey. Are you serious? We have to do this today?
Can I at least find the body first?
I just started.
I'm trying.
Do I have to do this today?
Oh shit, Uncle Russell.
I need you to pick up Uncle Russell.
It's not a mood if he's always in it.
Come on, man. You know that's my father.
Mom, how are you feeling?
China? You don't even like Chinese food.
Come on, Mom. You're healthy. You'll be fine. You've got your friends and family...
He'll be here soon.
I guess if people died every week, we'd see you all the time.
I'm alright.
"End up dead"?
When does dead beat sick?
Well that explains why you never call.
I guess it is.
18  CONTINUED: Ryan takes a seat in one of the chairs flanking the coffin.
By the way, I'm going to need that money.
The money for all this... the funeral.
That's Mom's money.
That's Mom's money.
So we're spliting the cost.
Yes. We are.
So?
What do you mean, you don't have it?
It's your family. You don't recognize them from the last funeral?
Who?
I have no idea. Maybe a friend of Dad's from work or something.
So, you're telling me I'm going to have to pay for the whole funeral?
I'm not a God damn credit agency!
Yes, um... We're just waiting for everyone to arrive, then we can get going. I know you're in a hurry.
Have you met my brother, Ryan?
No, no, I'm doing the eulogy.
Look, I think you should do the eulogy. Everyone's expecting you to do it.
Look most of the people are here for Dad, but let's not kid ourselves. A lot of them are here to hear your eulogy.
"My father was an exceptional man...
Can we talk about this when there's a little less death in the air?
Honey, I'm just not in the mood...
What? You don't have any panties on?
Babe, don't make it obvious, but that guy in the leather jacket standing by the wall. Don't look. Don't look.
Do you recognize him?
No, I don't think so. Don't look.
No, no, that's not it. He keeps looking at me. Don't look. Don't look.
Oh, Ryan can you keep an eye out--
Are you talking about Little Martina?
Can you keep an eye out for Uncle Russell?
Yeah, why don't you do that? See if she wants a juice box.
Hello.
Uh... thanks.
Frank?... I don't think so, no...
Well, nice to meet you. Thanks for coming.
Sure. Can we just wait five minutes for my Uncle Russell? We can't start without him.
As soon as Uncle Russell gets here we'll be ready to start.
Yeah.
Would you excuse me?
Every single person wants Ryan to do the eulogy. He was my father, too.
Come on, do I have to do this today?
Yes! Come in!
My father was an exceptional man...
Yeah, that's great. Do you mind if we do it later though? My uncle just got here.
Thank you, Derek, you're a life saver.
How are you doing, Uncle Russell?
What the hell is going on?!
Stole your parking space?!. My father's dead! Act right.
Good afternoon, everyone.
Thank you for coming... I never realized Dad was so popular. It looks like he's got more friends now that he's dead.

Dad's first job was working after school as an assistant to an electrician named Mr. Thompson. Back then, Blacks weren't allowed to wear rubber gloves. So my father got shocked a lot. Because of that, he had no feeling in his fingertips. I asked my Dad what his first boss was like...

.He said he was a nice man, and surprisingly well dressed. When Dad was eighteen, he left home after an argument with his father. He never told me what that argument was about, but I do know that after leaving South Carolina, sadly he and Bob lost touch and never saw each other again. Dad went to college where he studied accounting, a decision which lead to a career in corporate finance... But his real passion was for the arts, with a particular fondness for theatre, dance and musicals. He was a charter member of the Negro Ensemble Company and contributed regularly to the Alvin Ailey School of Dance.
What are you doing?
Elaine, what the hell was that?!
Oh, okay. My dead father's sprawled out on the living room floor, but it's okay, you're sorry.
No, I haven't made the call about the down payment yet.
No I'm not going to have sex with you.
What were you going to say?
Norman, please.
Why don't you show it to my Uncle Duncan? He's a doctor.
It's alright.
I guess so.
Oh yeah.
Sure.
Uh... yeah.
Actually I'm the oldest. I was writing before.he was. I've had a few pieces published in the New Yorker.
So anyway. What did you want to talk about?
Yeah. Okay. That's good.
Yeah, well Dad was a fun guy.
Sure.
So, where did you and my dad meet?
How did you know my father?
Oh God...
I had no idea.
Uugg. Like this.
Does my mother know?
"What's owed to you"?
What do you want?
Thirty thousand dollars?! I can't just give you thirty thousand dollars.
You think you can come in here, slander my father's name and show me a few photos of you and my dad dressed up going to see "Dreamgirls"? I saw "Dreamgirls" twice. I'm not gay.
I'm not giving you anything but a--
Wait here.
Oh God, oh God, oh God...
Ryan, I need to talk to you.
It's important.
That guy that was here before, that we didn't recognize...
Yeah.
Well, I was just with him in the study, and... and he showed me some pictures...
Pictures of him and Dad together at the premiere of "Dreamgirls".
Ryan, he was Dad's lover!
The guy in the leather jacket just showed me pictures of him and Dad together.
Uugg. I know.
You don't understand. If we don't give him the money, he's going to show Mom the picture.
What do you mean, you think I should pay him the money? Where the hell is all your money?
So after paying for the funeral, the clothes, the catering... Now I'm supposed to shell out thirty thousand dollars? He's your father, too.
I have not been living off of them...
No I haven't paid rent, but Dad hasn't worked in five years. Who do you think has been paying all the bills?
Would you mind giving us five minutes?
Thanks.
No. I'm really sorry, honey, but buying a condo is going to have to be put on hold, just for now.
Babe, you know I wouldn't do this unless I had a good reason.
I haven't got time right now, please.
Hey, hey, hey!
What are you doing with my manuscript?! It's not ready.
What's that supposed to mean?
Can we get to the point here?
If I write this check, then that's it.
What?
Yeah. So?
That's it. I can't do it.
There's no way in the world I'm giving him my hard earned money.
He comes in today! Of all days, he picks the day of my father's funeral!
So what. Who cares what he's got.
Let's just get it over with.
Ryan, what are you doing?
What?! I'm not a serial killer. I don't keep rope and duct tape in my pocket.
This is a really bad idea.
What am I supposed to do with the tie?
I don't know what to--
Apparently everything but write a damn check.
If I could tell everybody, it wouldn't be blackmail.
Yeah, Ryan, what are we going to do with him?

You don't know?! Come on, you're the big writer. You're the one who came up with "Black Hurt." Dream up something where we all live happily ever after. We can't keep him tied up forever. How long do you think those Valium are going to last?
What?
What?!
Jeff, what the hell are you doing with this stuff?
What friend, Amy Winehouse?
And you gave him how many?
Maybe we should call an ambulance.
So what then? What's going to happen?
Be out in a minute, Mom.
Sure. So sorry. Um... can you just give us another five minutes?
Why did you tie him up?!
What is wrong with you?
I'm not the one who tied him up.
I've been looking out for Mom since you got your book deal.
I couldn't leave because I had responsibilities.
At least I'm not some hack writing crap. Mr. "Mama's Secret", Mr. "Black Hurt."
Michelle, please, not now.
Listen... Do you remember the guy in the leather jacket?
Well, I don't know how to say this, but... it looks like he and my father were having sex.
Yes.
And now he wants thirty thousand dollars or he's going to show everyone photos of them doing... stuff...
Well, it's not that simple.
Norman, why are you grinning like that?
I'll be back soon. Can you check on Mom?
It's Aaron.
Oh shit! Call an ambulance.
What do you mean "there's no point"?!
Dead, dead?
What the hell did you do to him?
Well he was alive when I left.
Oh no. This is really bad. This is really, really bad.
Twenty-five to life.
Pull yourself together!
Didn't notice him? He's four fucking feet tall.
Get rid of the body?! It took me two months to get rid of a couch.
You want to bury him with my father?
That's not the point.
Norman!! Why is Uncle Russell on the toilet?
How could you forget?! What the hell is wrong with you?!
What is it?
Nothing.
Wait here.
I think I can get rid of this guy, but I need you to stay out here and try to stop anyone from coming in.
It's Aaron!
Everyone's out in the garden... We've gotta move the body now.
We can't leave it like that.
Be serious for a second.
Bye, Dad.
Yeah.
I'm so sorry, Uncle Russell. There was someone on the roof--
What dead body?
I can't believe what a nightmare today has been.
I can't believe I still have to do this eulogy... with everything I've just found out.
Not a thing.
Sure. Let's go.
My father... was an exceptional--
My father was an exceptional man.
Not only did he live for his family, but he was always there for others--
MY FATHER WAS AN EXCEPTIONAL MAN!!!

He had his... shortcomings, but he took care of his family. He loved his family. He loved this house. He worked hard. All I wanted today was to show him how much we all loved and admired him. To give him the respect that he deserved... Is that really so much to ask? We all get so distracted by the... little things in life. We forget about the important things.

So maybe he loved "Dreamgirls" more than most men. We don't know why a man makes the choices he makes. But I do know that my father made the best choices he could make. Life is complicated. We're just thrown here together in a world filled with chaos and confusion... and we do our best.
He taught us to go for what we wanted in life, because you never know how long you're going to be here... And whether you succeed... or you fail...

So when you all leave here today, I want you to remember Dad for who he really was... A decent, loving man who never condemned anyone for how they lived. Who never cast disparaging remarks or held prejudices against race, gender... height. If only we could all be as giving, as generous, as understanding as my father... Even dead, my father has more character than everyone in this room. If I am half the man my father was, my child will be incredibly blessed.
How's Mom?
That's not my father.
The wrong body?! Do they know where he is?
I told you not to use Marshals. But no, you wanted to keep it in the neighborhood. I know Swartz costs a little more, but at least they know where the bodies are.
Oh come on, honey. I'm sure it's not that bad.
Honey, it's going to be fine.
Baby, you're the oldest. You have to do the eulogy. Besides, I think you're just as good a writer as your brother. You just need to let someone read your book.
Sorry. Look, once this is all over, you know your mom's thinking about selling the house, so you know we've got to get out.of here.
You called them, right?
Aaron?... You put the down payment on the condo, right?

You better, because I can't live with your mother anymore. I've done my time, now it's time for your brother to take over. From now on, it's only Christmas and birthdays for us. Once we move, we can concentrate on your writing and our baby.
Yes. Today's the last day of this cycle.
What's taking you so long?
You want this baby as much me. Come on.
If I didn't want you to come, you would have done it five minutes ago.
Brian.
Cynthia, I--
Do you need anything, Cynthia?
How was the flight?
I'll make sure she's okay.
I'll make you a cup of coffee, Cynthia.
Tea?
Honey, we still need to finish that thing. Remember today is the last day.
No. No we can't.
I don't have any panties on.
I'm just trying to help you out. I'll put them back on before the service starts. Now come on.
Isn't that the guy from the Home Depot?
Did he put in the cable?
He's probably just a friend of your father's. I'll meet you in the garage. We have a few minutes before Uncle Russell gets here.
Honey. Can I see you for a moment?
Are you alright?
Calm down. Calm down. Forget about everyone. You're going to do the eulogy and it's going to be the best eulogy anyone's every heard. Now could you please do me a favor and get me pregnant?
Yes. What do you want? You want me to talk dirty? I'm gonna suck it.
It's alright, Cynthia. It's alright.
I wasn't going to say that.
I wasn't going to say that.
Hi.
Is everything okay?
What are you talking about? Why?
What's the reason?
Men.
How would I know? He's been avoiding me all day. We're trying to get pregnant. But I can't really do that by myself, can I? I feel like I'm making him eat brussel sprouts every time we do it.
Don't you think I know that?
It's a funeral, it's already ruined.
Aaron, what is going on?
Why are you acting like this? Fine.
Tell me what?
Yeah.
What? No. Not your father. With him?
No. Your father was the straightest guy I know.
Are you sure?
Stuff like what?
So that's it? We're just giving him all the money we've saved?
Why not?
How come you couldn't pay, Ryan?
Your novel?
You let him read your novel? You wouldn't let me read your novel. Are you screwing him, too? 'Cause Lord knows you're not screwing me.
Sure.
Hey, are you doing okay? It's going to be alright.
What are you doing?
Okay. I'll do what I can.
What about me?! I want a baby. Would somebody get me pregnant?!
Aaron?! Oscar's off the roof!
Hey, is he gone?
Thank God.
I don't know. It's been sort of exciting.
For a funeral, I mean...
We'll work it out. Let's just get this day over with. Then we can worry about the rest of our lives.
It doesn't change anything, does it?
Aaron gives her a look.
I hate funerals. It's all death, death, death.
I don't want a regular funeral. When I die, I want people to celebrate my life.
You still smoke?
I used to piss my pants too, but I stopped. The only thing I want black is my skin. At least open the window.
I've got enough problems of my own to deal with.
I told you... About the rash...
.on my hand...
Look at it.
What is it?
B.
Oh, damn.
If you hate funerals so much why are you coming?
Come on, man, leave Elaine alone.
So you're going to win her back over a dead body?
Hello?... How are you?... Okay..
Uncle Russell?! Damn! He's always in a bad mood.
Alright... 'Alright. I'll do it. See you soon. Bye.
There he is.
Hello, Uncle Russell. How are you?
There's nowhere to park.
Alright.
What the hell?
Elaine, I was going to park there.
Well, no, but I'm like family.
Aw, damn. I have Uncle Russell. How could I forget about Uncle Russell?
Yeah, alright!!
Ow.
Ow! That hurts.
What?
What about Uncle Russell? I need help with Uncle Russell!
Ow! Can you please stop doing that?!
Can I get a little help?
Yeah, well, you left me to push Uncle Russell up that damn hill all by myself. Then took all the credit.
40  CONTINUED: Elaine, turns around.
Hey, Elaine, I know you don't think I'm part of the family--
.but when you dissed me back there, I had Uncle Russell in the car.
You stole my parking space, and I had to push him half a mile up a hill. We almost missed the service!
She stole my parking space!
Are you alright?... That was insane.
Oh yeah... Sorry. It's just that you never know when it's your time. Like, I have this weird thing on my wrist.
He is? Great. Thanks.
Hello, Doctor, I know this is a bad time, but I've got this thing on my hand. I've had it for weeks now...
What do you think it is?
Really? Why? What do you think it is?
Pigment mutation?!
Nuts? What kind of nuts?
A pigment mutation?
It sounds serious, doesn't it?
A pigment mutation.
Ooh, will you try this cake? I think it might have nuts in it.
So?... Aaron's uncle says I might be allergic to nuts...
I can't not eat the cake. That's what I do when I'm stressed. I eat cake.
Will you just try it and tell me if there's nuts in it?
Come on.
Just do me a favor--
No. But can you try this--
Doctor, I just have a--
I'm sorry... you know... about... you know...
You think so?' I mean, there are a lot of fine ones up in heaven. Anna Nicole Smith's dead too, you know.
Death is a terrible thing... Did you check to make sure he.was wearing shoes? I hear they steal the shoes.
Before he died, did he have a rash?
Aaron, do you know what was in this cake, I-
What is going on? Who is that guy?
I just found some Valium outside.
It's okay. This should help. calm you down.
You said "shut the damn door."
He's having a seizure.
What are you going to do with him?
Yeah, I found that bottle of Valium.
Five.
I thought they were Valium.
Watch him?! What do you mean, "watch him"?
Can't you use the one upstairs?
What are we going to do?
Just looking for the key.
Yes, I've got you.
Alright, I'm trying to see where the toilet is.
No you do it.
Alright. Alright.
Who calls them "drawers"?
It's all down.
Yes, yes. Just sit down.
Ahh!!!
Ahh!!!
Please, please. Just come off.
What?
Oh, I think I've got some of it in my mouth!
Oh, no. Check him. Check him.
Check him again. Check him.
Wake him up. Wake up. Wake up. Wake up.
I don't know. Try Larry.
Shake him.
Maybe it's not Larry. Try something else. Pinch him.
He must be breathing. He has to be breathing. Please God let him be breathing.
Hi. Excuse me. Hi. Pardon me. Hi.
Can you come to the study for a second?
We didn't do anything!
Look, I'm not the prison type.
Thanks, man.
There's just no way we can do it.
I forgot!
I'm here.
Who is it?
Quick. Quick!
Hi!
So, what made you decide to get your God on?
I'd like to make a confession.
That's okay, 'cause I'm not Catholic.
What do you think God's favorite color is?
I'll bet it's blue. The sky's blue.
I'm addicted to strip clubs. The shoes, the poles, the smell. I just like to take my money and throw it in the air. I like to make it rain.
Oh that... It's probably nothing. I'm more worried about Hepatitis C after having Uncle Russell's shit in my mouth. I think I'm feeling yellow.
I don't think funerals are designed for anybody to really like.
Not me. I want it to be the saddest day ever. I want the stock market to stop. Schools to close. And no garbage pick-up.
You used to smoke.
Yeah? What problems?
Got to use condoms.
Still got to use condoms.
That's not a rash.
I don't know, but it doesn't look right.
You know why.
I can't. She's the one.
If I have to.
You didn't tell me the guy was in a wheelchair.
That truck is pulling out. Park there.
Hi, Elaine.
Your father invited me.
Did you see that?... She totally blew me off.
.barely even looked.
Stop the car, Norman.
Stop the car. I have to speak with her. I have to speak with Elaine.
Doctor, how nice to see you again.
Great. Great. We should have lunch soon. I'd love to hear what you think about the new pediatric wing at Cedar's.
You look nice, Elaine.
Yeah, but you make death look sexy.
So, I heard about the engagement.
Sure. Anything for you.
So that's him? That's the man you're going to spend the rest of your life with?
Elaine., I-
No problem at all.
You stink.
Oh, hi, Elaine. You following me?
Anything I can do to help?
I guess you've got it under control.
So what are you doing after the funeral? I've got Maxwell tickets.
How can she be more interested in that idiot than me? Women. They don't know what they want!
What?
So?
Then don't eat nuts. Put the cake down.
I bet you won't eat it when your arm falls off.
No.
I don't want to.
Get away from me.
Women are my problem.
She acts like she doesn't care that I exist. I mean how can she not feel what I feel?
Really?
Slap her? You want me to hit her?
Are you sure, 'cause that--
I just want to talk.
The only reason you don't want to go out with me is because your dad likes me.
Thanks.
Well I remember every minute of it.
What is it about this guy? What has he got that I haven't got?
It's funny. No matter what you say, I'm convinced we'll be together.
You still could.
I'm serious. You only live once. You might as well do whatever it is that makes you happy.
That's kind of cold. I care about you.
That's not true, Elaine.
Hey!
I'm the man for you, and you're coming home with me.
What is that?!
Norman, it's Derek. Let me in.
Are you in there?
Aaron, open the door.
Aaron, where's Norman?
It's Oscar, he went crazy. He's--
What's going on?
Look, Oscar's on the roof stark naked.
Did you hear that? She's having a kid!
How's your skin thing?
Are you okay?
About seeing my dad?
He doesn't hate you. He just loved Derek.
At least you know it's not you, so try not to get so nervous when he's around.
He's going to be more.concerned that his brother-in-law just died. He won't be focused on you. Anyway, when I tell him we're getting married, he'll have to accept you.
Oscar, calm down!
You heard the man, he ran a light.
Do you always open the door half naked? Come on, Jeff. We're going to be late.
Oscar's freaked out. A guy on a bike ran into the car.
It's okay, baby.
Go put your damn pants on.
Here. Take this..: It'll calm you down.
It's just Valium.
I used to take them all the time...
It'll be okay. I'll drive, honey.
Yeah. But he was sick for so long.
Shut up, Jeff.
What?
What the hell are you talking about?
Are you family, Norman?
No such thing.
What are you doing here?
Oh please.
Oscar, are you alright?
All this talking about phantom dogs and things being green... What's going on?
I don't know. Something's not right...
I think it's the Valium.
I gave him a Valium at your place. I think he's just not used to it.
It's so nice to see you.
I'll see you inside.
What? What is it?!
What do you mean it's not Valium?
This isn't funny, Jeff.
What the hell are you doing leaving that stuff around your house?!
I thought they were Valium!
What am I supposed to do? Should I tell him?
Hi, Dad. How are you?
He's my boyfriend. And you know his name.
I'm so sorry, Auntie. We're going to miss Uncle Edward so much.
Oscar, this is my Aunt--
I don't know. I can't leave. Aunt Cynthia would never speak to me again.
I'm dressed for a funeral.
Hey, hey. I don't really have time to deal with whatever happened between you and me. But I have not told my dad yet, so I would appreciate it if you would keep your mouth shut.
Yep, that's him.
Norman, shut up.
'Cause you're not.
Look, Norman, if you poke me one more time, I'm going to kick your ass.
See what?
What?
Oscar, please-
Oscar. Just calm down.
Oscar, please sit down.
Oscar, where are you going?
Ryan, no!
I'm so sorry, Aaron.
Please, Aaron. Go back inside. I'll explain later.
Dad, leave it alone!
It wasn't his fault.
I can't do that.
Because we're... moving in together.
Dad, this isn't actually what he's like. He took some drugs and--
No he's not on the pipe. He took some Valium and had a.bad reaction.
Dad, please.
Not right now, Dad.
Oscar.
Come and sit down.
Oscar, listen to me. I need to tell you something...
Now... You remember I gave you some Valium earlier?
Well it turns out that it wasn't actually Valium.
Can you hear me?
Do you understand? Hallucinogenic.
Oscar!
Oscar let go.
Oscar! Come back.
Excuse me. Sorry. Excuse me.
Excuse me. He's going to be sick.
Oscar.
Oscar, put down the dryer.
Oscar, please--
Oscar, are you okay?
Oscar, let me in.
Oscar. Oscar?
Oscar! Open the door.
Open the door. Oscar.
Oscar. Are you alright?
Oscar. Open the door.
Not really, thanks.
Oscar?
Oscar! Open the door.
Look... I'm busy. I don't have time for your shit. Now get the hell away from me!
Oscar!
Oscar?
Oscar?
Oscar?
Oscar.
Os...
Tell me about it... How's Aaron?
The guy's father just died. Don't you think this is a bad day for sex?
I'm sorry. At least your husband didn't ruin the funeral.
What do you want, Derek?
Please don't make me go through this again.
No. The reason I don't want to go out with you is because it was a mistake.
That wasn't a compliment. I'm saying I couldn't remember it.
A minute, huh? That's why I don't remember.
Okay, well for one thing, he's responsible. He's caring. He's considerate. He's thoughtful. He's stable. He's--
Yeah, well, we all make mistakes... I used to be convinced I was going to marry Prince. What happened there?
You're an idiot.
Yes, but maybe I don't think of life anymore as all about me, me, me.
No, Derek, you care about you. You only care about me in relation to how I affect you. There's a difference.
Derek, get over yourself.
Oscar!
Oscar! What are you doing? Get back here and put your clothes on right now!
I wasn't kissing him. I swear.
Calm down.
Remember you've got drugs in you.
Get out of here!
Oscar, please. Come back here.
Get back here. Be careful!
Oscar, come inside. We'll have some coffee.
Oscar!
Oscar... Please don't do this...
I wasn't with him.
Oscar, please just come inside.
Come with me.
Because you're going to be a father.
I'm pregnant. We're going to have a child...
I won't be able to do it without you.
Look, Dad--
No, I'm not staying out of this.
We're getting married.
I'm not marrying him because I'm pregnant. I'm marrying him because I love him.
Dad, this is my life. If you don't like it, too bad. But if you want to keep me and my child in your life, you'd better change your attitude, especially about my husband.
Yeah, just a little nervous...
I just don't think I've ever been so openly hated by anyone before.
Great. That makes me feel much better.
I can't help it. He puts me on edge.
Oh my God. Are you okay?
Are you sure? Is anything broken?
I could have killed you. What if you had cracked your head open? I'd have blood on my hands!
It came out of nowhere. I didn't see him. I'm sorry.
What is it?
Are you sure? I mean, I've got to drive.
Was there a dog in here just now?
Dalmatian? No, Schnauzer...
It's very green here, isn't it?...
What do you mean?
What are you talking about? I' fine .
Look... Isn't it beautiful?
I'm so sorry about... the death...
That saved a wretch like me...
Did you just see that?
The coffin just moved.
I'm telling you I saw it move.
There, look. It happened again.
That coffin's moving!
The coffin's moving!
There's someone alive in there!
What the hell is wrong with you people?!
There's someone moving in there.
No, I have to show you! He's alive!
But the coffin was moving.
Elaine.
I swear it was moving. I must be losing my mind...
Why are my hands so big?!
What is it?
Yes.
Hello?
You!
How long does it last?
Eight hours?! Of this?!!
I'm going to be sick.
Stand back!
Get back or I'll blow your head off.
Okay. Breathe.
It's going to be okay. Breathe.
Snap out of it! You can handle this.
Alright. You're okay. Stay calm...
That's it, Oscar, keep it together.
DO THEY!!!!
Replies.Didascalie: (CONT'D) (he screams at himself in the  MIRROR)

Replies.Reply: Easy now. Easy now. We can do this.
Where's my watch?!
Oh!
It's already been...
Five minutes.
God damn! Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit!
Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit!
Ahhh.
Yes, yes. Keep coming. Join the others. Join the others.
Oscar?
Oscar?
Oscar.
.car.
I saw you kissing him.
You cheater! You cheater! You're committing adultery!!!
I'm going to jump right now.
I'm going to jump. I'm jumping.
I'm going to jump. She's cheating on me!
I believe I can fly! I believe I can touch the sky!
No!
Then why were you with him?
Yes, you were! I saw you!
I'll never be good enough. Not for your dad, and not for you.
No. You go inside.
Why?
What?
You're pregnant?
We're having a baby.
Thank you.
Bye, Dad.
I knew it! I knew it!
Yeah, I'm fine.
It was my fault. I ran a light.
Who's picking up Uncle Russell?--
There were so many things we wanted to do... We were going to go to China.

That's not the point. I haven't been feeling good. Who knows how long I'm going to live without him. It happens all the time. One spouse goes and then the next. I mean, it might be different if I had a grandchild to take my mind off of everything.
Where is Ryan? Have you heard from him?
Just seeing that boy's face makes me feel better. I've missed him so much.
Yeah, you can get your hand off my husband's coffin. You're leaving smudge marks.
Ryan!
You always know exactly what to say, Ryan. I'm so glad you're here.
I'm trying to hold it together, Duncan. He was a really good husband.
They don't make 'em like my Edward anymore. A good husband and a great father to two healthy, strong boys.
Coffee can do many things Michelle, but it can't bring back the dead.
Elaine... Jeff... good to see you.
Thank you.
Duncan, I'm going back now.
In a moment.
Thank you. I'll be alright. I know he's watching over me.
Ryan?
Aaron?
Reverend Davis wants to talk with you.
Is everything okay, boys?
If you've never given life, child, how can you understand death?
Baby, I really think we should start again now. Have you seen Uncle Russell?
You bastard!
He was with you!

Yeah, I found them. The ones in the Valium bottle?... Yeah... I'll get them to you this evening... Can't do this afternoon... It's your fault you left them here... I've got a funeral... My uncle died... Yeah, tragic... No, I haven't taken any. I saw what they did to you... What are they anyway?...
I've gotta go, my sister's here...
Hang on!
Hey, what's up?
I've just got to put my pants on and I'm ready.
Is he okay?
I'm going. I'm going.
Ready. Let's do it.
So, poor old Uncle Eddie...
Dead? Since when does dead beat sick?
I love when you come to family functions, Oscar. Because then Dad focuses all his hate on you.
Oscar?
Elaine, what's wrong with Oscar?
Valium?!
Oh, right.
Elaine, can I speak to you for a minute?
I have to tell you something and, I'm warning you in advance, you're not going to like it.
I mean what you thought was Valium, wasn't actually Valium. It's a hallucinogenic. Like, acid, mescaline... Special K...
I'm not being funny. Look at him, he's high as a kite!
A friend left it. And who the hell just goes into someone's house and takes pills?
No, don't do that. It'll just freak him out... We'll just keep a close eye on him, and make sure he doesn't get out of control... And don't let him spend too long talking to one person... or bush.
Hi, Dad.
No, no. It's all worked out. Don't worry.
Yeah. He was a great guy.
What are you going to do?
Yeah, now, the best thing to do is relax and just go with the flow. Try and enjoy it.
I don't know... eight hours?
Uh... Elaine... I can't find the pill bottle?
You haven't seen a pill bottle around, have you? A Valium pill bottle?
Have you seen a little brown pill bottle lying around--
What's going on?
Why is he all tied up?
He's blackmailing you? Over what?
Valium?
Ah shit!
The thing is... those pills aren't really Valium. It's acid and... acid.
Oscar took one by mistake. That's why he's acting crazy.
A friend left them at my place.
Five?!
Poor bastard.
You can't do that. I'll go to jail.
No... I don't think so... I doubt it.. Probably not...
I can't believe you gave him five.
Hello?
We'll stick him behind the couch.
Ugh!
Norman? Norman?
Norman!
You missed some.
Pull yourself together. Would you rather get caught or have shit in your mouth?!
Hey, man, you alright?
Man. Hey. Hey!
What's his name?
Larry?
Larry, wake up. It's time to get up.
He's dead.
There's no point.
Look at him! He's dead!
He hit his head on the table.
What are we going to do?
You're not going anywhere.
Did any of you happen to notice the size of Uncle Edward's coffin?
Why not?... I mean it's not like he's going to know.
I've got to go.
I have to go out there. If he jumps, my sister is going to kill me.
Hello! Mom!
I know this is hard, Mom. But you're going to be okay.
I'm always here for you, Mom.
Aaron, how are you?

Okay. I had to buy the seat next to me because I don't trust the airlines with my bags. And there was a lot of turbulence... I guess that's the thing about flying first class. It doesn't matter how much you pay if the plane crashes, you still end up dead--
Oh damn.
It's hard to see Dad like this. But he's in a better place now.
I guess you're right. This is why I try not to get close to people.
What do you want me to say? Some families talk to each other all the time, some just see each other at funerals. That's us.
What money?
What about the insurance?
What about the pension?
Oh.
Are we?
Oh, okay.
I don't have it right now.
And that's why I don't have any cash.
Nice to see you again.
Who are all these people? I don't even recognize half of them.
So what side of the family is he on?
The guy in the leather jacket.
No I'm telling you you'll have the money in a few months when I get my advance.
I'm sure the Lord will forgive you.
Aaron is the oldest.
No, they're not. You're the oldest.
So imagine how surprised they'll be when they hear yours.
God damn, that Martina has grown up.
She was like a teenager when I left, and now she's... you know. She's like damn.
I think I should go see how she's been.
I was just telling him how much I'm looking forward to hearing your eulogy.
What the hell is wrong with you?!
Please let me extend my apologies to you all. I understand the incident you just witnessed was quite shocking, but everything will be... returned...
Good, good. Thanks a lot.
.so you've never been to New York?
Oh, that's not really seeing New York.
Great. All star weekend is in New York this year.
Not now, Aaron.
Give me five minutes.
What are you doing? What is it?
The guy in the leather jacket?
What about him?
So? He showed you some picture?
Look, is this going anywhere, Aaron?
What? No, no, no.

No, no, no. I don't believe that. My father is not gay. I've known him my whole life. And he's the most non-gay man I've ever met. Matter fact, he's so straight he makes me seem gay. And I know I'm not gay--
Uugg.
Okay. Let me think, let me think.
I think you should pay him the money.
I'm in debt up to my ass. I'm broke, man!
You're the oldest. Besides, you've been living off Mom and Dad long enough. You must have some money saved. You haven't paid rent in two years.
Well if you've got money problems and I've got money problems, what can we do? Fuck him!
You've got to pay him.
You? So you and my--. You?! It's you. So when I called my father and he didn't answer, he was with you?!
It kind of is...
Thanks... I guess...
Aaron, what are you doing?
Don't be stupid. Not today. I'll pay you back as soon as my money comes in.
He has the pictures!
What? No, wait.
Let's just discuss this a minute.
Aaron, help me!
Aaron, you got any rope or duct tape?
Well just grab something!
There, from the curtains.
Tie his legs.
Get that tie.
Whatever you do with a tie.
Just stuff it in his mouth! Damn, I have to do everything?
Shut the goddamn door!
He's having a seizure.
Yeah. Great. Give him some.
Norman! I told you to lock the damn door.
Look, just trust us. He's the bad guy. We'll explain later.
I don't know.
What is it?
Wait, you're telling us that Elaine's boyfriend, who knocked over our father's coffin, had just one of these things...
He's right. If anyone finds out this guy's been force fed acid, we could all be arrested.
Damn.
Okay. We have to go out there. You two stay in here and watch him.
Just make sure he doesn't escape.
Why didn't you just pay him the money?!
Do you want Mom to find out?!
Well somebody had to look out for Mom.
You just can't get over it, can you?
Don't put it off on responsibilities.
Mr. "Out of Ink", Mr. "Blank Page." At least my crap gets published.
Just tell her, Aaron.
That's what I thought.
Aaron refused to pay.
That's not the point. Besides, the only reason Aaron tore up the check is because the guy started talking bad about his novel.
Is there a "kind of" dead, Aaron?
Look, no one here knows who this guy is. Nobody knows his name. They probably didn't even notice him.
Look, all we have to do is get rid of the body. It'll be like he came and left.
You have to admit, it makes sense, Aaron. The coffin's there, the hole in the ground's there... He'll be gone, finished, end of story...
Oh shit. Put him in the bathroom.
Where are you going?
Let's go!
Make sure no one comes in.
Aaron, we have to do this.
In a strange way, this might have been what he wanted.
Why do you say I don't take anything seriously? You complain about me all the time, but if I didn't play the bad boy, you couldn't play the martyr.
Aaron's so great, Aaron's so right, Aaron's so responsible.
Why don't you try laughing and enjoying life once in a while? It might make you a better a writer.
I know you did, Russell. We all did.
What the hell are you doing in my Dad's coffin?
She's resting.
I've asked Mom to come live with me for awhile. It'll give you and Michelle a chance to breathe a bit, you know. Move and everything.
Where the fuck have you been, you fat bastard? You're late. If you took any longer I'd be dead, too.
What's happening?
I said what's happening? Are we there?.
What the hell is going on?
You're going the wrong way!
What's going on here? Where are we?!
What are you doing?! Be careful with that.
Hurry up, we're late.
Come on, put your back into it.
Terrible.
Move! Move!
Why isn't Ryan doing the eulogy? This is bullshit.
It wouldn't have happened if Ryan had done the eulogy.
I read your last book, "Black Hurt."
I'm not giving you a compliment you arrogant bastard. What a load of bullshit. I wouldn't wipe my ass with it.
Don't worry. The way you look, you won't be far behind.
No, my nephew is dead and these bastards ate all the potato salad.
What's your problem?!

No such thing as having a woman without a problem. If they didn't have problems, do you think they'd let us touch 'em? Let me tell you something about women. Smarter than you think they are. But not as smart as they think they are.
Oh she feels it. She's playing hard to get. She wants you to work for it.
Listen here, boy. This is what you do: you walk up to her, slap her--
Has not hitting her worked? Look, then you grab her and kiss her. The harder the better.
Oh, man, I gotta shit. Where's the can?
Hello?!
I need the toilet.
I'm in a wheelchair, you idiot! How am I supposed to get up the stairs?!
Open the damn door!
What the hell is wrong with you people? I'm about to take a dump in my pants!
Hurry up!
Have you got me?
Come on, quick, quick, quick.
Pants down. Pants down.
How can I do it? I'm handicapped.
Drawers. Drawers. Take down my drawers.
Am I there? Am I there?
Ooh, that's better.
What's that?
What the hell is going on in this place?
Never mind that. What about that dead body you dragged in here?
Don't mess with me. I know a dead body when I see one. I live in a retirement home.
I'm telling you I saw the guy. He was dead!
No! In the bathroom.
I always thought he had a little sugar in his tank.
Aaron, how are you?
Yes, I have two more funerals and a Christening. I don't know what it is about the Spring, but they're either coming in or going out.

Ah, the writer, of course. I must admit I squeezed this job in because I wanted to meet you. I'm reading "Mama's Secret" right now. Don't tell anybody, I'm not supposed to be reading that kind of stuff.
You must be very proud of your big brother. He really made something of his life.
I can't wait to hear your eulogy.
Oh. I thought...
Great... Well, I'll just make sure have everything I need.
We've got a body and a Bible. Well, I'm all set.
I think we should get started.
.Of course.
Family and friends, we're gathered here today to mourn the passing of Edward Barnes.
I'd like to start with a favorite passage of Edwards from First Samuel chapter 18, verses 1-4 in the King James Bible.

"And it came to pass, when he had made an end of speaking unto Saul, that the soul of Jonathan was knit with the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul. And Saul took him that day, and would let him go no more home to his father's house..."
."Then Jonathan and David made a covenant, because he loved him as his own soul..."
."And Jonathan stripped himself of the robe that was upon him, and gave it to David, and his garments, even to his sword and to his bow, and to his girdle."
And now we'll have a few words from Edward's son, Aaron. Ryan's older brother.
Are you alright?
Ah! I think we're just about ready to start the service, so-
Of course.

Lookie here, brother. I've been patient. We all know it's a virtue, but I'm about done with patience. Now if we don't resume service soon, we're going to need to have a little conversation about my compensation.
Five minutes.
I'm not a priest.
I have no idea.
Look, I must get to a phone. There's a man on the roof who's going to jump.
We're going to have to fly through this now. I already missed a funeral and two Christenings.
Do you want an open casket?
Alright! Everybody in their seats now!
Hey, you, sit down.
I'd like to apologize on behalf of the family for all of the distractions. I hope that everyone is settled and ready to continue with the service.
How's my little sister?
That was horrible.
Aaron. How are we doing on time?
So what's this I hear about Ryan not doing the eulogy?
That's a shame. I mean, I'm sure you'll be good, Aaron. It's just with Ryan being the writer of the family...
There are people here that don't even know your father. They just came to hear Ryan.
So any new books coming out? I just finished "Black Hurt.
Not bad considering we're at a funeral.
How's Pepperdine treating you? Is Professor Clarke still giving you a hard time?
I'm not worried about you.
So I see you brought your friend.
Derek. How are you doing at the hospital?
Definitely. Maybe Elaine would like to join us for lunch?
Get away from there!
I'll kill him!
Leave it alone?! He just knocked my brother-in-law out of his coffin.
Yes it was. My sister is in tears. I can't believe you brought this idiot!
Why not?
Are you crazy?
Drugs?! Is he on the pipe?
Valium?! That's not a Valium high.
I just want to point out that you won't see Derek knocking over a coffin.
Fine. I've got to check on Cynthia, but this isn't over.
You should probably go see a dermatologist.
I don't know. It looks like some kind of pigment mutation.
You're probably just allergic to something. Maybe from shellfish, nuts...
I don't know. Pecans? Peanuts?...
I'm sure we'll start soon.
Let's go inside.
Elaine, what are you doing?!
Elaine!
Elaine!
Great.
I'm going to kill him.
Elaine!
Thank God you're safe.
You idiot! What the hell is wrong with you? Stay away from my daughter.
Elaine, stay out of this.
You're what?!
Elaine, you don't have to marry him just because you're pregnant.
How can you love him? He's an idiot.
What the hell is going on?
Hi there.
I was really sorry to hear about your dad. He talked about you a lot. I saw your wedding pictures. Your wife's dress was very beautiful.
Something like that, yeah.
Actually, there's something I'd like to talk to you about... when you have a minute.
Sure.
Grief does strange things to people.
If you remember, I have something to talk to you about.
Is there somewhere private we could go?
Are you writing a novel?
Like your big brother.
Oh. Well, you must be very proud of your brother then. Getting all his novels published.
Your father and I were very... close.
And we spent a lot of time together.
Um... I've got some photos I want to show you.
That's me and your Dad in Central Park in New York.
That's us on Santa Monica Boulevard on Halloween...
Just around.
That's one of me and your father going to the premiere of "Dreamgirls". I was dressed as Deena and your father had to be Effie.
Are you really that shocked?
I'm sorry. I'm sure he would have eventually told you, but I guess he wasn't sure how you'd react.
No. And there's no reason why she should... Just as long as I get what's owed to me.
I'll tell you how it makes me feel cheap. Like some cheap piece of ass... I mean, I'm entitled to something.
What I want is a lot, but I'm not asking you for what I want. I deserve thirty thousand dollars.
Your father told me you were having trouble...
Look, your father promised to take care of me, and I made sacrifices to keep him happy.
Now I don't want to, but I will show these photos to your mother... Do you really want me to do that today?
Well, you left it on a coffee table.
Well, when you put things on coffee tables, it's assumed it's for everybody.
Fine by me.
Deal.
Is it your first one?
The novel... it's a first draft?
No, nothing.

I tried writing once... Didn't work for me, either. I think it's just a gift. You either have it or you don't... It must be hard for you though, especially since your younger brother is such a great writer.
Your father and I read "Black Hurt"
Fine. This is on your head.
Get out of my way.
There's nothing to discuss.
Get out of my way.
Get out of my way. Move!
Get off me!
Ah!!
What?
Hello?
Hello?
Edward! Edward! Edward!
No! No!
Did he ever mention me?... Frank?
Is there more soda in here?
I'm so sorry to hear about your uncle.
Frank gives Aaron a knowing look.
Aaron, I was just telling George here how when we were boys together your dad used to love to make us all go skinny dipping.
I've been with my parents once.
I turn eighteen next month.
I know. I know.
Edward and I watched the Tony Awards every year. We would get all dressed up and sip cocktails. I'm going to miss him so much.
Aaron walks off to join Ryan, who's at the door of the study.
Norman makes his way to the door.
